bibl.title: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, May 17, 1942

div1.p: Truby is not convinced that Hench's specialty is needed in the armed services at this time. He also tells Hench that he has heard of Andrus' death and credits Andrus with having provided a reliable account of the “events in Cuba.”

div1.head: Letter from Albert E. Truby to Philip Showalter Hench, May 17, 1942
div1.opener:
Rutledge Pa.
May 17/42
Dear Dr. Hench:
div1.p:
Your letter was awaiting me on the 15th
when I arrived here from New York. I remained
there longer than I had expected to stay. Now
I have to change my plans again and
will be in Washington for at least a
couple of weeks before returning here.

I was so glad to learn that you were able
to take your mother home with you and that
she was improving.

Regarding your entry into the service for
work along the lines of your specialty, I
feetl that you really are not needed yet
for that work. Later on when men in large
numbers are returning from foreign service
there no doubt will be many suffering from
rheumatic conditions. The S.G. will then
probably have send cases cared for at some
special hospital, possibly at Hot Springs, and
your services at such a place would be most
valuable. Your impediment of speech should
not, in my opinion, interfere in any way
with the fine service you can render to
AC
T
2
the Government.

Hillman and Lull are good sound
men and will know best when and how
you can best serve in this emergency.
I doubt very much if there is any
rheumatic problem at the present time.
The Army just now is dealing with young
physically fit men. Only under the
Stress & Strain of Lord campaigns would, (I think)
there be much likelyhood of rheumatic
conditions on a large scale. Of course,
I am speculating on this from past experience
and am not qualified to give you the
news of the S.G.O.

In other words I feel that you will be
needed in time, but that there is nothing
urgent at present to demand your entry
into the service.

My address in Washington will be: --
1831 Summit Place N.W.

I may go to Atlantic City for the A.M.A.
If not I may be able to see you either
in Washington or Philadelphia. Rutledge
is a hard place to get to and I would
be glad to come to Phila. to see you if I
am at Rutledge at that time.

I have just learned that J.H. Andrus
died on May 1, for dilatation of the
right ventricle. Autopsy showed a
tumor in the upper cervical region of
the Spinal Cord about 5 mm. in diameter.

In my opinion his memory of the events
in Cuba was more reliable and accurate
than any I was able to obtain from
other sources.

Our 45th reunion was a most
enjoyable affair and your story the “Conquest
of YF” was responsible for my being
called upon for quite extensive remarks

Let me know your plans for your
trip to the A.M.A. and I will do my
best to arrange my affairs so that
I can meet you.
